item.title: Why Business Needs Unified Communications
item.description: By: John Shepler There was a time when the only way to communicate electronically was with that clunky black phone on your desk. While that phone might still be there, modern technology has made it lighter and brought a wealth of new communication methods. Email, text messages, mobile phone calls, and video chats are now commonplace across various devices like desktops, laptops, tablets, smartphones, and even watches. A significant challenge, particularly in business, is that these platforms and applications don’t always work well together.

item.title: India is enhancing its intellectual property infrastructure
item.description: The Indian government has decided to continue its efforts to improve its intellectual property (IP) offices. This initiative, part of the 12th Plan (2012-2017), will cost Rs309.6 crore, with Rs258 crore allocated for the 12th Plan and Rs51.6 crore for the 13th Plan. This decision recognizes the increasing importance of IP in a globalized economy, India’s recent membership in the Madrid Protocol (April 2013), and the Controller General of Patents, Designs, and Trademarks (CGPDTM) office’s new role as an International Searching and Preliminary Examining Authority (ISA/IPEA) under the Patent Cooperation Treaty (starting October 2013).

item.title: From T1 to Ethernet
item.description: While your local area network (LAN) might be operating smoothly, connecting to the broader internet for services like dedicated internet access, direct data transfers, or VoIP calls often requires a different approach. T1 lines offer a budget-friendly solution, but they use a different protocol than the Ethernet standard common to many LANs. Fortunately, modern T1 providers simplify this process with managed routers. These specialized routers are designed to handle the technical aspects of T1 lines, including signal conversion, data framing, and impedance matching.

item.title: Steppin' Out With My Ethernet
item.description: Ethernet is the standard way we connect computers in a local network. Carrier Ethernet extends this familiar technology beyond the office to connect locations across cities and even countries. While other technologies like DSL and fiber optics offer similar connectivity, Carrier Ethernet provides simpler management. It’s like having very long wires connecting all your offices, factories, and warehouses as one network. The other major advantage? Lower costs. Specialized Ethernet providers utilize modern IP networks and are rapidly expanding their reach to connect businesses.

item.title: Advantage of Dedicated Cloud Connections
item.description: Companies of all sizes are increasingly adopting cloud services due to their cost-effectiveness. However, the assumption that a basic internet connection is sufficient for accessing these services is proving to be inaccurate in many situations. While the internet’s widespread availability and affordability make it appealing for WAN services, its security concerns led to the development of VPNs. These secure tunnels encrypt data, allowing remote workers and branch offices to connect securely to corporate networks and transfer sensitive information.

item.title: Today is the day for the landrush of .global, .website, and .press domain names
item.description: Starting August 27th, Singapore time, several top-level domain names will be up for grabs in a “landrush” phase, according to online brand specialist IP Mirror. The “sunrise” phase, reserved for trademark holders to register their brands, precedes this period. During the landrush phase, anyone can secure remaining domain names at a premium price. IP Mirror highlights “.global” as a particularly appealing option, signifying a broad international reach. This domain’s landrush phase lasts from August 27th to September 4th.

item.title: Why Telephone Wiring is a Thing of the Past
item.description: The traditional telephone network, known as POTS (Plain Old Telephone Service), utilizes a vast network of thin copper wires connecting buildings to local telephone exchanges. This system, designed solely for analog communication, efficiently serves businesses using traditional phones and low-speed devices like fax machines. Imagine two parallel road systems: high-speed freeways representing computer networks and slower county roads symbolizing the telephone network. Coexisting within the same regions, each serves distinct traffic needs.

item.title: Trademarks from Asia in a world that is interconnected
item.description: Asian brands aiming to go global don’t have the luxury of slowly building a reputation over decades, according to experts who spoke at the 136th annual meeting of the International Trademark Association (INTA). This information was shared in a newsletter by IP Mirror, a company specializing in domain name registration, cloud hosting, and brand protection. Source: INTA website. The event, held in Hong Kong in early May, highlighted several strategies for Asian brands expanding globally, as reported by IP Mirror:

item.title: Carrier Ethernet Providers Expand
item.description: A significant development in network connectivity over the past few years has been the nationwide rise of Carrier Ethernet services, and this trend is gaining momentum. Here’s why you should consider it for more affordable metropolitan, long-distance, and last-mile connections using the Ethernet protocol. You might be wondering about the buzz surrounding Carrier Ethernet, especially since bonded T1, DS3, and SONET fiber optic services have been available for years and their prices have been steadily declining.
